awd_titl_txt: Co-Evolution of Cosmic Rays and Thermal Plasma in Galaxy Clusters
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explore the physics and observational consequences of cosmic rays in galaxy clusters.  Clusters of galaxies formed early in the history of the Universe, and are still growing by pulling in matter from their outskirts and occasionally merging with other clusters. As matter is added, it creates heat, much as meteors are heated as they fall through the atmosphere of the Earth. At the same time, the environments surrounding supermassive black holes at the centers of galaxy clusters spew forth matter and energy in spectacular bursts. The medium into which all this, heat, matter, and energy are poured is a plasma – a fully ionized gas so hot that instead of emitting visible light, it glows in x-rays. About one in ten billion of the charged particles within this plasma is a cosmic ray - so energetic that it travels at nearly the speed of light. The goal of this project is to unravel this complex dance of mass and energy input, understand how it creates a plasma and cosmic ray mixture, and predict how it will appear under the lens of radio, x-ray, and gamma-ray telescopes existing now and planned for the future.  The project will also provide research training for graduate and undergraduate students from traditionally under-represented groups.

X-ray observations of galaxy clusters reveal that about 40% of their baryonic matter is in the form of a pervasive, 10 – 100 keV plasma known as the Intracluster Medium (ICM). The ICM carries a magnetic field with tangled topology and hosts an energetically significant population of relativistic cosmic rays, which are observed at radio frequencies and were expected to be detected in gamma-rays of hadronic origin, which puzzlingly have never been seen. Understanding energy partitioning and transport in the ICM, from global scale gravitational infall at the cluster outskirts and supermassive black hole activity at the center, to the microscale waves and instabilities that thrive in the absence of frequent Coulomb collisions, is a multi-scale non-equilibrium plasma physics problem. Progress has only recently become possible due to advanced computing resources and algorithmic breakthroughs that enable numerical simulation of ICM plasma almost from first principles. A team of graduate and undergraduate students led by faculty members at the University of Wisconsin - Madison collaborating with scientists at the Los Alamos National Laboratory will use these opportunities to comprehensively model, for the first time, the joint evolution of thermal plasma, relativistic cosmic rays, and turbulence. Radiative outputs of the calculations are expected to lead to detailed predictions that will be tested by radio, x-ray, and gamma-ray observations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Decades of observations have revealed that  galaxies such as our own Milky Way are not uniformly sprinkled throughout space, but reside near other galaxies, forming groups and clusters. The largest such clusters known in the Universe today harbor thousands of galaxies. The James Webb Space Telescope has revealed that clusters were already forming when the Universe was a few hundred million years old, less than 10% of its present age, and have continued to grow over cosmic time, drawing in increasing numbers of galaxies  through the inexorable force of gravity.

With the advent of x-ray astronomy, it was realized that galaxy clusters are pervaded by, a magnetized, ionized gas, or plasma, that is so hot it emits only in x-rays. From the observed rate at which this intracluster plasma radiates, we can estimate how long it would take to cool below x-ray temperatures, fall toward the cluster center, and perhaps become dense enough to form stars. This time is less than one tenth the age of the Universe. From this, we infer that something must be heating the gas to maintain it at its high temperature. But although it has been known for half a century that cluster gas has been heated, how it is heated is not yet understood. To add to the complexity,  galaxy cluster plasmas carry strong electric and magnetic fields, and host a population of high energy electrons and protons called cosmic rays. A montage of cluster images showing galaxies, hot gas, and radio waves emitted by cosmic ray electrons interacting with the cluster magnetic field is shown in Figure 1.

Under the auspices of this project, we explored a mechanism called magnetic pumping, through which magnetic fields transform the energy in large scale flows - arising, for example, as galaxy motion "stirs" the hot plasma by moving through it - and transforms it to heat. This mechanism is known to operate in the solar system and the Earth's magnetosphere - but could it also work in galaxy clusters? We showed that it can, and that it is powerful and efficient enough to be a major part of the solution to the hot gas haeting problem. And, we serendipitously discovered that a type of plasma wave burst mechanism previously identified only in the magnetosphere can also operate in galaxy clusters.  This sent us off in an entirely new direction, which we are pursuing with a new NSF grant, to understand how these bursts of waves affect the flow of heat from hotter to cooler plasma. It also appears that these bursts can cause drastic changes in the plasma temperature. Some results related to an article we published in The Astrophysical Journal are shown in Figure 2.

Who is "we" and how did we do it? In this case, "we" is a senior professor of astronomy and physics (the PI) and an evolving team involving two undergraduate students who both are now pursuing graduate studies, a graduate student who is now a postdoctoral scientist, and a postdoctoral scientist who is planning to build upon the knowledge of astrophysics, plasma physics, and scientific computing gained in this project to study how the energy of fusion plasma can be harnessed to provide clean power,
